oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Dury, George
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Abraham Lincoln, 1809-1865, President of the United States
Portrait of Abraham Lincoln funded by the Tennessee Legislature during Reconstruction
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Lincoln sitting in red chair facing to his left.

Professional artists dependent upon wealthy patrons risked losing business as a result of partisan attitudes. Some left Tennessee, moving either north or further south to avoid having to take sides publicly.Those who stayed carefully toed the line of neutrality, like painter-photographer George Dury, who painted figures from both sides of the war. The Reconstruction Legislature, also known as the Brownlow Legislature, also commissioned a full-length portrait of Gov. William G. Brownlow from Dury.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Lincoln, Abraham, 1809-1865--Portraits
Walking a Fine Line
